description: From Middle English forstanden, from Old English forstandan (“to defend, help, protect, withstand, prevent, hinder, resist, oppose, benefit, avail, understand, signify, be equal to”), from Proto-Germanic *frastandaną (“to understand, oppose”), equivalent to for- +‎ stand. Cognate with West Frisian ferstean (“to understand”), Saterland Frisian ferstounde (“to understand”), Dutch verstaan (“to understand”), German verstehen (“to understand”). Compare also Norwegian Bokmål forstå (“to comprehend, understand”), Swedish förstå (“to comprehend, understand”).

verbs.description: forstand (third-person singular simple present forstands, present participle forstanding, simple past and past participle forstood)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To stand against; stand in front of so as to bar the way; block; oppose; withstand.
examples: "As he would more of them had not wise God, Wierd forstood him, and the man's courage."
How can I forstand your Professors, when they dinna forstand themselves."
